questions.question_text: In the current RF environment, the noise floor is -95 dBm. A tablet needs an SNR of 25 dB to transmit at the required speed. What must the RSSI cell edge be to meet the required SNR?

discussion.content: WMM shortens the Interframe Spacing requirements for high priority packets so that voice and video can be sent in bursts without the need to wait as much for lower priority data in between. Additionally, WMM is needed in order to obtain 802.11n and 802.11ac data rates. This means that with WMM disabled or for non-WMM clients, the maximum usable data rate is 54 Mbps.

choices.B: Set Quality of Service (QoS) to Silver.
choices.C: Set Quality of Service (QoS) to Platinum.
choices.A: Set WMM mode to Optional or Required.

discussion.content:
The answer is correct but this question has a Typo.
802.11af has nothing to do with POE.

Question should ask: What happens when a Cisco 3702 AP is connected with 802.3af?

802.3af provides up to 15.4 watts.
802.3at provides up to 25.5 watts.

Cisco 3702 needs 802.3at to run full power in 4X4 mode.
When powered by 802.3af it must reduce power by disabling one transmit and one receiver to make it 3X3.

choices.B: fail to boot in CAPWAP mode
choices.D: enable the 2.4-GHz radios with 40-MHz channel bonding

questions.question_text: An engineer has just deployed a Cisco Aironet 3702 Access Point with an access layer switch that supports IEEE 802.1af Power over Ethernet. How will the access points react to the wattage that is available in 802.1af?
Following a WLC upgrade you want to check what version of code the access point is running. Where can you find this information?

discussion.content:
In my opinion ABD are correct but the best answer is D.
A and B basically show the same (the IOS version of the controller) that technically is the same IOS version that are running the joined APs. However, if you want to check the IOS version of an specific AP then the best way is go to GUI > Wireless > Access point > General

Sorry, but show running config is not valid on LWAPs.
Option D gives you the software version of an AP.

comments.content:
Juaxoo, you are correct. 
It does not specify from where you are checking, that is what confused me.
Show running config is a valid command on the AP, so the answer is correct.

The Answer is D from the Controller to verify the AP SW version
.
What I mean is that this question looks very similiar to Question #53 where the correct answer is D. They both mentione AP code version.
I'm not so sure about that, they are asking to verify which version the access point is running. Not the controller.

discussion.content:
Correct answer is A.
There is currently no "Show running-config" command for controllers. There used to be but it has been phased out.

Current Cisco instructions for upgrading tell you to check with "Show sysinfo"
This is done on the controller CLI, but the AP will upgrade itself with the same code.

Verify
In order to verify the version of WLC software that is running, log in to the controller after the system reboots.



After upgrade, from CLI:
(Cisco Controller) >show sysinfo

choices.E: MAC layer data encryption and decryption
